oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Don Williams Interview - Biff Collie [Unedited]
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of an interview with Don Williams (performer) conducted by Biff Collie. Segment is recorded on an unknown date.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Don Williams; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie and Don Williams discuss details of Collie's introduction -- (00:19) Collie introduction of the 'Don William's Theatre' -- (00:27) Collie and Williams joke about the introduction and both discuss the order to which the show will be -- (01:27) Williams describes the meaning behind the Pozo Seco Singers' name -- (02:43) Williams describes the songs he recorded by Mike Merchant and Collie inquires about Bob McDill -- (03:25) Collie has Williams visualize the feeling of success of a song -- (05:11) Collie introduces Williams, and challenges Williams to reflect on images being placed upon the Pozo Seco Singers -- (08:42) Collie has Williams reflect on his relationship with Wayland Holyfield -- (09:49) Collie introduces Williams from commercial break and Williams reflects on his success in England -- (11:40) Collie and Williams discuss the messages associated in Williams' music -- (12:50) Collie attests to the therapeutic nature of writing music and Williams describes his desire for satisfaction -- (13:57) "Say it Again" writer McDill is addressed by Collie and Williams describes how he relates to McDill -- (14:54) Collie attempts radio spot introducing Williams -- (15:06) Collie radio spot introducing Williams -- (15:27) Williams and Collie articulate how Williams tries to present himself -- (18:16) Collie introduces "Some Broken Hearts Never Mend" -- (18:35) Collie introduction of Williams from commercial break -- (18:52) Collie and Williams discuss Williams being compared to soft-spoken people -- (22:17) Williams and Collie discuss Williams' geographical upbringing -- (22:56) Williams begins to reflect on "I'm Just a Country Boy" before trailing off -- (23:31) Williams and Collie discuss the inevitability of "I'm Just a Country Boy" -- (24:14) Williams is curious about the editing process -- (24:41) Collie introduces Williams, and both reflect on Williams' previous work history and Williams desire to be a writer -- (26:14) Collie invites Williams to discuss his forty acres -- (26:38) Collie introduces "Tulsa Time" and invites Williams to discuss the origins of the song -- (28:01) Collie inquires about the duration Williams remains on the road -- (29:41) Collie inquires about which song was last introduced, and both Collie and Williams discuss Danny Flowers -- (30:41) Collie introduces Williams from the break, and Williams and Collie discuss the amount of instrumentation Williams uses -- (32:26) Collie and Williams discuss the benefits of live road sound -- (34:05) Collie introduces an unidentified tune likening it to Williams -- (34:50) Collie introduces a Bob Wills tune [unidentified], and both discuss Williams' hobbies -- (36:19) Collie and Williams discuss Williams' childhood aspirations to be a singer -- (38:10) "I Believe in You" is revealed to be about Williams' wife, and Collie and Williams discuss the meaning of a spouse -- (38:51) Collie introduction of Williams from commercial break, and both discuss Williams' international success helping his local success -- (42:22) Collie and Williams reflect on the meaning of awards -- (43:29) Collie asks Williams what he would do with his free time -- (44:48) Collie praises Williams, and both discuss Williams' actions speaking for him -- (45:28) Collie praises Williams and both say their goodbyes
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Williams, Don, 1939-; Williams, Don, 1939-2017; Collie, Biff;
